conclusion: Determine the length of the transparent part of all the light entering perpendicular to MN on the lens spherical surface.
Light source is at the focal point F of the parabolic reflector.
Light rays emitted from F will be reflected parallel to the axis of the parabola after hitting the parabolic surface.
Parallel light rays enter the hemispherical lens perpendicularly to the vertical diameter MN.
Light rays are incident normally on the spherical surface of the lens and do not bend.
Light rays continue in a straight line inside the lens.
The length of the transparent part is determined by the diameter of the circle where the light rays enter the lens.
The radius of the circular cross-section is equal to the radius R of the hemispherical lens.
The diameter of this circle is 2R.
Assume the radius R is the same as the height of the car headlights from the ground, 92.8 cm.
Calculate the diameter: 2R = 2 x 92.8 cm = 185.6 cm.
The length of the transparent part of all the light entering perpendicular to MN on the lens spherical surface is 185.6 cm.
